skill.name: memory-safety-patterns
skill.description: Implement memory-safe programming with RAII, ownership, smart pointers, and resource management across Rust, C++, and C. Use when writing safe systems code, managing resources, or preventing memory bugs.
skill.summary: Implement memory-safe programming with RAII, ownership, smart pointers, and resource management acro...

security_audit.summary: The skill content is documentation and code examples for memory safety patterns. No data access, network calls, or execution logic is present.

content.user_title: Apply memory safety patterns in systems code
content.value_statement: Memory bugs cause crashes and security flaws in systems code. This skill provides proven patterns in Rust, C++, and C to prevent them.
actual_capabilities: Explain RAII patterns for file, mutex, and transaction handling in C++
Demonstrate smart pointer usage with unique_ptr, shared_ptr, and weak_ptr
Describe Rust ownership, borrowing, lifetimes, and shared ownership types
Provide C cleanup patterns including goto cleanup and opaque pointers
Outline bounds checking approaches in C++ and Rust
Show data race prevention patterns with atomics and locks
limitations: Does not analyze or modify your codebase automatically
Does not run sanitizers or external tools for you
Does not provide language-specific build configurations
Does not guarantee correctness without code review

use_cases.title: Prevent memory bugs
use_cases.description: Apply RAII and ownership patterns to reduce leaks and use after free errors.

use_cases.title: Modernize resource handling
use_cases.description: Replace raw pointers with smart pointers and safe container access.

use_cases.title: Understand ownership rules
use_cases.description: Learn borrowing, lifetimes, and safe shared ownership patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Explain RAII basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain RAII with a short C++ example for file and mutex handling. Keep it concise and practical.

prompt_templates.title: Choose smart pointer
prompt_templates.prompt: Given a graph with parent and child links, explain which smart pointers to use and why.

prompt_templates.title: Translate to Rust
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how a C++ RAII pattern maps to Rust ownership and borrowing concepts.

prompt_templates.title: Race free design
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend a data race prevention approach in C++ and Rust for a shared counter and map.

output_examples.input: Summarize safe resource management options in C, C++, and Rust.
output: C: use goto cleanup blocks or explicit create and destroy functions
C++: use RAII with destructors and smart pointers
Rust: rely on ownership, borrowing, and drop semantics

best_practices: Tie resource lifetime to scope using RAII or ownership
Prefer safe containers and bounds checked access
Use tools like sanitizers and static analysis during development
anti_patterns: Using raw pointers without clear ownership rules
Returning references to stack local data
Ignoring compiler warnings about unsafe access

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. It is plain guidance and examples that work across these platforms.

faq.question: What are the limits of the guidance?
faq.answer: It provides patterns and examples but does not validate your specific code.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my build or CI system?
faq.answer: No. It only offers recommendations and command examples.

faq.question: Does it access my files or data?
faq.answer: No. The skill contains static text and code examples only.

faq.question: What if I still see memory errors?
faq.answer: Use sanitizers or debuggers and review ownership and lifetime rules.

faq.question: How does it compare to a linter or sanitizer?
faq.answer: It teaches patterns, while linters and sanitizers detect issues in real code.
